label: logicC:astronomy_en
steps: [1] If a star's light curve shows periodic dips, then it has a transiting companion.
[2] If a star has a transiting companion, then the companion's radius can be estimated from the transit depth.
[3] If the companion's radius is known and the star's radial velocity shows a matching period, then the companion's bulk density can be computed.
[4] The star's radial velocity shows a periodic signal matching the photometric period.
[5] The star's light curve shows periodic dips.
[6] For any object x, if x is a gas giant exoplanet, then x has a hydrogen-dominated atmosphere.
[7] Planet a is a gas giant exoplanet.
[8] For any object x, if x has a hydrogen-dominated atmosphere, then its spectrum shows either methane or water absorption.
[9] The star has a transiting companion. (from [1] and [5])
[10] The companion's radius can be estimated from the transit depth. (from [2] and [9])
[11] The companion's bulk density can be computed. (from [3] and [10] and [4])
[12] Planet a has a hydrogen-dominated atmosphere and its spectrum shows either methane or water absorption. (from [6],[7],[8])
